item.title: Deltarune Chapters Three and Four "100%" Coming in 2025, Toby Fox Says
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/deltarune-chapters-three-and-four-2025

Deltarune creator Toby Fox has provided an update on the release timing for the game's long-awaited third and fourth chapters, and it sounds like you've got reason to be optimistic if you're excited to play them.

In a thread on X (formerly Twitter), Fox first wishes his followers a happy Halloween before celebrating Deltarune's sixth anniversary. Unfortunately, yes, it really has been that long since the game's first chapter was released.

Fox then provides an update on Deltarune chapters three and four, which he says will "100%" be released next year. There's not much room for doubt in that statement, eh?

According to Fox, he can't divulge a more specific release window for the third and fourth Deltarune chapters owing to "localization and console porting", so we don't technically know exactly when the two chapters will arrive.

However, if Fox keeps to his word, then it's likely one of the chapters will release earlier in the year, and the other will launch later on. I wouldn't expect the two of them to arrive simultaneously, as fun as that would be.

If you're not familiar with Deltarune, it's a followup to the 2015 hit Undertale, and the name is also an anagram of that game's title, although it doesn't take place in the same world.

Much like Undertale, however, Deltarune allows you to decide whether to tackle battles violently or peacefully, and it also features bullet hell-inflected turn-based combat. Some characters, like Alphys, return directly from Undertale, while others, like Ralsei, nod to similar Undertale characters.

Deltarune's first chapter arrived in 2018, and its second chapter followed three years later in 2021.

In late 2022, Fox announced that the third and fourth chapters wouldn't be released that year, but just over a week later, he promised that development on the game would be "smoother" going forward.

Deltarune chapters three and four are due to launch sometime in 2025. Until then, you can check out the game's first and second chapters entirely for free on PC, PlayStation 4, and Nintendo Switch.

item.title: Call of Duty Series Tops 500m Sales, Black Ops 6 Enjoys Franchise's Biggest Launch
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/call-of-duty-series-sales-black-ops-6-launch

Activision has announced that Call of Duty series sales have topped the 500 million mark, and Microsoft has also revealed that Black Ops 6 enjoyed the series' biggest launch ever.

Speaking to the Washington Post, Activision confirmed the massive sales milestone for the first-person shooter franchise, and that milestone likely explains why Microsoft's gaming revenue increased 61% in the first quarter of the 2024-25 fiscal year, with 53 of those points driven by Activision.

Additionally, in an earnings call (via Eurogamer), Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella described Black Ops 6's launch as "the biggest Call of Duty launch ever", pointing to its "record for day one players as well as Game Pass subscriber adds on launch day".

Nadella didn't give any specifics regarding sales figures or Game Pass subscriber adds for Black Ops 6, although as Eurogamer notes, he did previously say that Bethesda's spacefaring RPG Starfield set a similar record last year.

Nevertheless, this monumental success, as well as Call of Duty's sales figures as a whole, will no doubt add to the happiness Nadella feels about scoring an eye-watering payrise this year despite massive layoffs across his company.

If you've somehow missed out on the hype, Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 is the latest game in the long-running and phenomenally successful Call of Duty franchise.

The game is a co-development effort between longtime Black Ops studio Treyarch and Raven Software, who also collaborated on 2020's Call of Duty: Black Ops Cold War. It boasts a single-player campaign, as well as the usual multiplayer and zombies modes.

Despite its massive success, Black Ops 6 has garnered its fair share of controversy as well, with elements like its always-online campaign and paid audio package drawing fire from irate fans.

In any case, Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 is available right now on PC, PlayStation, and Xbox, and it's also playable via Xbox Game Pass Ultimate and PC Game Pass, although not via Xbox Game Pass Standard or Core.

item.title: Ubisoft Hemorrhaging Money After High-Profile Flops
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/ubisoft-h1-2024-25-fiscal-results

Ubisoft has released its financial results for the first half of the fiscal year, and if you've been following the company's fortunes recently, then it probably won't come as a shock to you to learn that things aren't looking good.

In its financial summary, Ubisoft reveals that it's effectively hemorrhaging money right now; the company lost €271.8 million in the period between April and September this year, and it's currently staring down the barrel of around €1 billion's worth of debt.

In addition, net bookings are down 22% year-on-year, while digital revenues have fallen 27% and player spending (although Ubisoft uses the somewhat ghoulish term "recurring investment") has fallen 39% compared to the same period last year.

These doomy numbers are likely driven largely by the apparent failure of Star Wars Outlaws, which Ubisoft has admitted didn't perform according to its expectations, although the company doesn't mention the game in these latest financial results, nor does it give official sales numbers.

Rather cunningly, Ubisoft refers to its "unique player" count rather than its sales in an accompanying presentation, declaring that "more than 30 million unique active players" played Rainbow Six Siege and the Assassin's Creed franchise over the last twelve months.

The company also says its cost reduction plan is "well on track", with its "total headcount" dropping by over 2,000 over the past 24 months.

All in all, the presentation and its accompanying slideshow paint a pretty grim picture for Ubisoft, and that's probably a result the company doesn't feel it needs after a prolonged period of turmoil.

Ubisoft's annus horribilis arguably began with the launch of Skull and Bones back in February, with critics and players alike responding to the long-awaited pirate game with a resounding "eh".

Following that, a prominent investor in the company called for "strategic and structural change" in September, calling out perceived failures in management and company policy on the part of Ubisoft's owners the Guillemots.

Major release Assassin's Creed Shadows was subsequently delayed to February 2025, alongside which Ubisoft revealed that Outlaws had underperformed and confirmed a return to day-one Steam releases for its PC games, as well as the abandonment of the traditional season pass model for DLC.

More investor threats followed, alongside a declaration of employee strike action over return-to-work policies and poor pay. All of that is in addition to a data policy lawsuit that Ubisoft is currently facing.

Of course, none of these issues stopped Ubisoft releasing a rather oddly-timed NFT game last week. One rather suspects this isn't the sort of strategy Ubisoft needs to get back on track, but I suppose we'll have to wait and see.

item.title: Valve Now Requires Devs to Disclose Kernel-Level Anti-Cheat Measures on Steam
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/valve-steam-anti-cheat-disclosure

Valve has announced that developers who want to put their games on Steam will need to disclose whether those games are using any kind of kernel-level anti-cheat software going forward.

Announcing the changes via the Steamworks community page, Valve says this is a change that's been requested by both developers and players; devs want better options to "share anti-cheat information" with players, while players are requesting more anti-cheat "transparency".

To that end, a new field has been added in which developers can indicate the anti-cheat software that comes with their game. If a developer's game contains kernel-level and client-side anti-cheat measures, then those measures must be disclosed via this new field.

This also applies to games that are already on Steam, so developers who are currently using kernel-level anti-cheat solutions will need to add this disclosure to their games' Steam pages.

If games are using anti-cheat that isn't kernel-based or is server-side, then their developers aren't technically required to disclose this information, but Valve says it thinks that letting players know about this would be beneficial on both sides.

If you're a Steam developer, you can find this new option in your Steamworks landing page, under the "Edit Store Page" heading. A new "Anti-Cheat" option will be available, and Valve says it's made a list of the most common software providers so you can easily fill out the field.

It's worth noting that even if a Steam page already discloses its measures somewhere else in its text, then that information should now be migrated to the new field and removed from the existing area.

Plenty of games use kernel-level anti-cheat measures, with big guns like Halo Infinite, Sea of Thieves, and more incorporating it into their online components.

However, some games have been the subject of controversy due to their anti-cheat measures.

Back in 2022, for instance, a vulnerability was discovered in Genshin Impact's anti-cheat protocols potentially allowed hackers to bypass users' virus protection, and the game didn't even need to be installed for players to be susceptible.

In July that same year, VR social platform VRChat implemented Easy Anti-Cheat, one of the most popular anti-cheat solutions, thereby also banning the use of mods for the platform, a decision that wasn't exactly received well by the VRChat community.
